docTitle.titlePart:
Development of a DGPS/MEMS IMU Integrated System for
Navigation in Urban Canyon Conditions

byline.docAuthor: S. Godha and M. E. Cannon

byline.affiliation:
Position Location and Navigation Group (PLAN)
Department of Geomatics Engineering
Schulich School of Engineering
University of Calgary,

front.address: 2500 University Drive N.W., Calgary, Alberta, CANADA, T2N 1N4
front.div:
Abstract. The aim of this paper is to develop a
DGPS/MEMS INS integrated system, which is able to
provide a navigation solution with accuracy levels
appropriate for land vehicle navigation. The system
achieves this aim by augmenting the standard GPS/INS
Kalman filter with additional sensor error states, like scale
factor errors and sensor turn on biases, which prevent the
growth of errors in a stand-alone INS navigation solution,
to some extent. To achieve high accuracy positioning in
areas with restricted GPS coverage, the GPS and INS
sensors are integrated at the measurement level. Further,
to improve the accuracy of stand-alone INS during GPS
outages, the use of two vehicle dynamic constraints is
proposed. The goal is to derive observations from
constraint equations reflecting the behavior of a typical
land vehicle. The first constraint equation is derived
assuming the vehicle does not slip and always remains in
contact with the ground. If these assumptions are true the
velocity of the vehicle in the plane perpendicular to the
forward direction should be zero. The second constraint
equation is derived from the fact that the height does not
change much in a land vehicular environment. Thus,
when a GPS outage occurs, the integrated system uses a
complementary Kalman filter to combine the INS and
constraints-derived virtual measurements to keep the
position and velocity errors bounded. The obtained results
show that RMS horizontal accuracies of up to 6 m in the
position domain can be achieved, from the designed
DGPS/MEMS INS integrated system in a severely signal
degraded environment. With the proposed use of virtual
measurements obtained from vehicle motion constraints,
the accuracy improved by about 40% thereby constraining
the horizontal errors to less than the 4 m level.
front.keyword:
Keywords. Differential GPS (DGPS), Inertial Navigation
System (INS), Tightly Coupled Integration, MEMS IMU.
